article: I lived near Johns Hopkins Hospital, and we rented our upstairs rooms to outpatients .  One summer evening as I was _ supper, I opened the door to see a truly _ man. His face was lopsided from swelling , red and raw. Yet his _ was pleasant as he said: "Good evening. I've come to ask to stay here for _ one night. I came for treatment this morning from the eastern shore." He told me he'd been hunting for a _ since noon but no one would take him in. "I guess it's my face..." For a moment I _ , but his next words convinced me: "I'll sleep in this rocking chair on the porch . My bus leaves early in the morning." I told him that we would find him a bed inside. When we were _ for supper, I asked if he would join us. "No, thank you. I have plenty," he said,48 holding up a brown paper bag. When I had finished the dishes, I went out on the _ .The old man told me his story - about 50 _ he fished to support his family. It didn't 51 _ me very long to realize that he had a big heart. We let him sleep in a folded bed in the children's room. When I got up in the morning, the sheets were neatly _ and the little man was outside again. He refused breakfast, but just before he left for his bus, he asked: " _ I stay here again the next time I receive treatment? I can sleep fine in a chair." He paused a moment and then54: _ "You made me feel at home." I told him he was 55 _ anytime. The next time, he arrived a little after seven in the morning. He56 _ us a quart of the largest oysters I had ever seen. He said he had caught them early that morning57 _ he left so that they'd be fresh. I often thought of a58 _ our next-door neighbor made after the man left the first time."Did you keep that man last night? You'll lose customers by 59 putting up such people!" Maybe we did60 _ a few. But who wants customers like that - ones who would prejudge a wonderful person based on appearance?
